questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient is undergoing evaluation for voice changes. The ENT surgeon reviews the laryngeal muscle function and asks the resident to match specific laryngeal muscles to their corresponding actions on the vocal cords. Match the following muscles (List A) with their primary functions (List B):

 

List A (Laryngeal Muscles):

 

  1. Posterior cricoarytenoid
  2. Lateral cricoarytenoid
  3. Cricothyroid
  4. Vocalis

 

List B (Function):

 

  1. Abduction of vocal cords
  2. Adduction of vocal cords
  3. Tension regulation of vocal cords
  4. Pitch modulation by fine-tuning the vocal ligament

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid (1-A): The only abductor of the vocal cords, opens the glottis.
  • Lateral cricoarytenoid (2-B): Pulls vocal cords medially, thus acts as an adductor.
  • Cricothyroid (3-C): Increases tension of the vocal cords by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward.
  • Vocalis (4-D): Fine-tunes pitch by adjusting tension in segments of the vocal ligament.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intrinsic muscles of the larynx control vocal cord abduction, adduction, and tension—posterior cricoarytenoid abducts, lateral cricoarytenoid adducts, cricothyroid tenses, and vocalis fine-tunes pitch.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with aspiration during swallowing. The ENT specialist suspects impaired function of the muscles acting on the laryngeal inlet. Match the following intrinsic laryngeal muscles (List A) with their corresponding actions on the laryngeal inlet (List B):

 

List A (Muscles):

 

  1. Thyroepiglottic muscle (part of thyroarytenoid)
  2. Interarytenoid (oblique part)
  3. Aryepiglottic muscle (posterior oblique part of interarytenoid)

 

List B (Action):

 

  1. Closes laryngeal inlet
  2. Opens laryngeal inlet
  3. Assists in vocal fold tension
  4. Abducts vocal folds

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-A

 

  • Thyroepiglottic muscle (1-B): Part of the thyroarytenoid complex, opens the laryngeal inlet by pulling the epiglottis forward and upward.

 

 

  • Interarytenoid – oblique part (2-A): Closes the laryngeal inlet by bringing the arytenoids together and pulling the aryepiglottic folds inward.

 

 

  • Aryepiglottic muscle (3-A): A continuation of the oblique interarytenoid fibers into the aryepiglottic fold, helps in closing the laryngeal inlet during swallowing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroepiglottic muscle opens the laryngeal inlet, while the interarytenoid and aryepiglottic muscles act to close it.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 284

questions.text:
A medical student is asked to classify the extrinsic muscles of the larynx based on their function and attachment. Match the following muscles (List A) with their correct functional classification (List B):

 

List A (Muscles):

 

  1. Stylopharyngeus
  2. Mylohyoid
  3. Sternothyroid
  4. Omohyoid

 

List B (Function):

 

  1. Primary elevator of larynx
  2. Secondary elevator of larynx
  3. Depressor of larynx
  4. Adductor of vocal cords

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-C

 

  • Stylopharyngeus (1-A): A primary elevator, directly attaches to the thyroid cartilage, elevating the larynx during swallowing.

 

 

  • Mylohyoid (2-B): A secondary elevator, attached to the hyoid bone, elevates the larynx indirectly.

 

 

  • Sternothyroid (3-C): A depressor of the larynx, pulls the thyroid cartilage downward.

 

 

  • Omohyoid (4-C): Also a depressor, pulling the hyoid bone and hence the larynx downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extrinsic laryngeal muscles act as elevators or depressors based on their attachment to either thyroid cartilage or hyoid bone.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 284

questions.text: A 28-year-old female schoolteacher presents with progressive vocal fatigue and hoarseness, especially after long teaching hours. She denies smoking or any history of recent upper respiratory infection. Indirect laryngoscopy shows a key-hole-shaped glottic gap during phonation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phonasthenia

 

 

This clinical picture is classic for Phonasthenia, a voice disorder caused by fatigue of phonatory muscles like the thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles, especially after vocal overuse or misuse. It is commonly seen in teachers, singers, or speakers.

 

The hallmark features include:

 

  • Easy voice fatigue
  • Laryngoscopic signs:
    1. Elliptical gap – suggests weakness of thyroarytenoid
    2. Triangular gap posteriorly – suggests interarytenoid weakness
    3. Key-hole shaped glottis – suggests both are involved

 

Treatment is conservative—voice rest and vocal hygiene education.

 

Phonasthenia: Correct. Fatigue of phonatory muscles with key-hole glottic gap and voice fatigue strongly suggests this.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Vocal cord nodule: Presents with bilateral small nodules at the junction of anterior and middle third of the cord. Laryngoscopy does not show a key-hole pattern.

 

 

Option C. Unilateral vocal cord palsy: Would show immobility of one vocal cord, not a key-hole-shaped gap.

 

 

Option D. Functional aphonia: Presents with whispering speech and cords seen in abducted position but normal movement during coughing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phonasthenia is characterized by vocal fatigue with a key-hole-shaped glottis on laryngoscopy due to weakness of both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 314

questions.text: A 40-year-old teacher presents with a strained, effortful voice and frequent voice breaks. Her symptoms worsen with prolonged speaking. Laryngoscopy reveals no structural abnormality, but flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy shows spasmodic closure of the vocal cords with tremors of the larynx and palate during phonation. CT and MRI of the brain are normal. What is the best treatment to relieve her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Botulinum toxin injection to thyroarytenoid muscle

 

This is a classic case of adductor spasmodic dysphonia, a type of focal laryngeal dystonia where:

 

  • Adductor muscles (mainly thyroarytenoid) go into intermittent spasm, causing:
    • Strained or strangled speech
    • Phonation breaks
    • Normal appearing larynx structurally

 

 

Key features in this case:

 

  • Profession requiring prolonged voice use (teacher)
  • Symptoms worsened by talking
  • Intermittent voice breaks with no anatomical lesion
  • Tremors seen on flexible laryngoscopy
  • Normal CT/MRI (used to exclude neurological causes)

 

Botulinum toxin injection to thyroarytenoid muscle: Correct. This is the first-line treatment. It relieves vocal cord spasms and improves voice. Injections may need repeating every 3–4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voice therapy only: Not effective alone in adductor dysphonia. Can be used as adjunct to botulinum toxin.

 

Option B. Reassurance and psychotherapy: Outdated approach. The disorder is not psychological in origin, though it was once thought to be.

 

Option D. Sectioning of the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Considered only in severe and refractory cases. Carries high risk of breathy voice and aspiration due to glottic insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adductor dysphonia is best treated with botulinum toxin injection into the thyroarytenoid muscle, which reduces vocal cord spasms and improves phonation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 314

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection into posterior cricoarytenoid muscles

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a gradually progressive breathy voice. She reports worsening symptoms while speaking on the telephone or under emotional stress. Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy reveals intermittent glottic opening during speech, with no structural abnormality. MRI brain is normal. The likely diagnosis is confirmed. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum toxin injection into posterior cricoarytenoid muscles

 

This patient is presenting with signs of abductor spasmodic dysphonia, a rare form of laryngeal dystonia involving spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, the only abductor of the vocal cords.

 

 

Key clues:

 

  • Breathy voice and breathy voice breaks
  • Symptoms worsen during telephone use and stress (typical of abductor type)
  • Normal appearing larynx on exam and normal MRI (used to rule out neurological causes)

 

Treatment approach:

 

  • Botulinum toxin injection into the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is first-line
    • Can be given via percutaneous EMG-guided or endoscopic route
    • Only ~50% respond, with shorter duration of benefit than adductor type
    • Caution: May risk airway obstruction if over injected

 

Botulinum toxin injection into posterior cricoarytenoid muscles: Correct. First-line treatment. Though response is limited, it remains the best initial step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroplasty Type I: Considered when injection therapy fails. Not first-line.

 

Option C. Gelfoam injection into vocal cords: Temporary measure used to predict efficacy of permanent thyroplasty. Not a primary treatment.

 

Option D. Voice therapy alone: Ineffective when used alone. Always used in combination with other treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abductor dysphonia is best managed initially with botulinum toxin injection into the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles, though outcomes are less predictable than adductor type.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 315

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes thyroid surgery for a multinodular goitre. Postoperatively, he presents with hoarseness of voice. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals one vocal cord in a paramedian position with failure to abduct during inspiration. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior cricoarytenoid

 

Posterior cricoarytenoid: Correct. This is the only abductor of the vocal cords. It opens the rima glottidis during inspiration. Paralysis due to injury to this muscle or its innervation (recurrent laryngeal nerve) results in a paramedian fixed cord and hoarseness.

 

 

Option A. Lateral cricoarytenoid: Incorrect. It is an adductor that closes the vocal cords. Injury would affect phonation but not abduction.

 

 

Option B. Cricothyroid: Incorrect. It is a tensor of the vocal cords, responsible for pitch modulation. It is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

 

Option D. Thyroarytenoid: Incorrect. It acts to relax and adduct the vocal cords. Its paralysis does not affect abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle that abducts the vocal cords; its paralysis causes the vocal cord to remain in a paramedian position, leading to hoarseness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Chapter 61 – Larynx, pg 350–352
